Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Situation2: They notice a small discrepancy in the register but it doesn’t affect the total sales for the day.
Story:
I stared at the flickering screen in the break room, my mentor’s email open in front of me. The code sample she’d assigned was more complex than I’d expected, and she wanted it done before our next meeting in three days. I knew she’d ask detailed questions, and I didn’t want to let her down. But my shift as a cashier was about to start, and I had to put my mentee worries aside for now.

As I rang up customers, my mind kept drifting back to the unfinished code. Then, during a lull, I noticed a small discrepancy in the register—just a few cents off, nothing that would affect the total sales. Store policy said I should report any irregularity, no matter how minor. But if I did, I’d have to fill out paperwork and stay late, eating into the precious time I’d set aside to work on my assignment. My mentor expected me to be prepared, but my manager expected me to follow every procedure to the letter. I felt the pressure building inside me, torn between the two roles, knowing I couldn’t meet both expectations at once.
